metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: describe light as a transverse electromagnetic wave which is produced by the acceleration of charges, which in turn produces changing electric fields and associated changing magnetic fields

transverse_wave_nature.name: Transverse Wave Nature
transverse_wave_nature.correct: Electromagnetic waves are transverse: the electric and magnetic field oscillations are perpendicular to the wave's direction of travel.

longitudinal.error: Longitudinal waves have oscillations parallel to travel direction.
longitudinal.fix: In EM waves, E and B fields oscillate perpendicular to travel, not along it.
longitudinal.action: Draw an EM wave. Check: do E and B oscillate sideways or along the wave?

circular.error: EM waves oscillate in straight lines, not circles.
circular.fix: The fields oscillate back and forth along perpendicular axes, not in circular paths.
circular.action: Trace the E field in a diagram: it goes up then down, not around.

spiral.error: EM waves are planar oscillations, not helical.
spiral.fix: E and B fields oscillate in perpendicular planes, not spiralling through space.
spiral.action: Compare EM wave diagrams to a spring: EM waves are flat, not coiled.

persistent.gap: You do not understand what transverse means for waves.
persistent.action: Compare transverse (water waves) vs longitudinal (sound). EM waves are like water waves: oscillation is perpendicular to travel.

field_perpendicularity.name: E and B Field Orientation
field_perpendicularity.correct: In an electromagnetic wave, the electric field, magnetic field, and direction of travel are all mutually perpendicular.

parallel to each other.error: E and B are not parallel; they are perpendicular.
parallel to each other.fix: E and B form a right angle with each other and with the travel direction.
parallel to each other.action: Use your right hand: point fingers along E, curl toward B, thumb points in travel direction.

at 45 degrees.error: The angle between E and B is exactly 90 degrees, not 45.
at 45 degrees.fix: E and B are perpendicular, meaning 90 degrees apart.
at 45 degrees.action: Draw E vertical and B horizontal. They meet at a right angle.

varying angle.error: The angle between E and B is fixed at 90 degrees, not variable.
varying angle.fix: The perpendicular relationship is constant; only the amplitudes vary.
varying angle.action: Check any EM wave diagram: E and B are always at right angles.

persistent.gap: You do not visualise the geometry of EM waves correctly.
persistent.action: Build a 3D model: E on y-axis, B on z-axis, wave travels along x-axis. All perpendicular.

em_wave_production.name: EM Wave Production
em_wave_production.correct: Electromagnetic waves are produced when charged particles accelerate. Stationary or constant-velocity charges do not emit EM radiation.

stationary charges.error: Stationary charges have static fields; they do not produce waves.
stationary charges.fix: Only accelerating charges produce changing fields that become EM waves.
stationary charges.action: Think: a stationary charge has a constant E field. No change = no wave.

charges moving at constant velocity.error: Constant velocity means no acceleration; no EM wave is produced.
charges moving at constant velocity.fix: The charge must be accelerating to produce EM radiation.
charges moving at constant velocity.action: Acceleration means velocity is changing. Only changing motion creates waves.

any moving charge.error: Constant-velocity motion does not produce EM waves.
any moving charge.fix: Only acceleration creates the changing fields needed for EM radiation.
any moving charge.action: Key distinction: moving at constant v ≠ accelerating. Only acceleration radiates.

persistent.action: Remember: a = dv/dt. If v is constant, a = 0, no radiation. If v changes, a ≠ 0, radiation occurs.

changing_electric_field.name: Changing Electric Field
changing_electric_field.correct: When a charge accelerates, its electric field changes in strength and direction, creating a disturbance that propagates outward.

constant electric field.error: An accelerating charge does not have a constant field.
constant electric field.fix: Acceleration means the field is changing in time.
constant electric field.action: Picture an oscillating charge: the E field direction flips as the charge moves.

no electric field.error: All charges have electric fields; acceleration changes them.
no electric field.fix: The field exists; acceleration causes it to change and radiate.
no electric field.action: Charges always have E fields. Acceleration makes those fields time-varying.

static electric field.error: Static means unchanging; that applies only to stationary charges.
static electric field.fix: An accelerating charge has a dynamic, time-varying electric field.
static electric field.action: Static = not moving. Accelerating = definitely changing. Different situations.

persistent.gap: You do not connect acceleration to field changes.
persistent.action: Visualise: charge moves up, E points away. Charge moves down, E reverses. Oscillation = changing field.

changing_magnetic_field.name: Changing Magnetic Field Production
changing_magnetic_field.correct: A changing electric field produces a changing magnetic field perpendicular to it. This is Maxwell's key insight.

static magnetic field.error: A changing E field produces a changing B field, not a static one.
static magnetic field.fix: If E changes, B must also change. Static fields do not propagate as waves.
static magnetic field.action: EM waves require both fields to oscillate. Static fields stay local.

no magnetic field.error: A changing E field always produces a B field.
no magnetic field.fix: Maxwell showed changing E creates B. That is fundamental to EM waves.
no magnetic field.action: No changing B means no wave propagation. Both fields are required.

constant magnetic field.error: The B field must change along with the E field for wave propagation.
constant magnetic field.fix: In EM waves, both fields oscillate at the same frequency.
constant magnetic field.action: Check: in EM wave diagrams, E and B both have peaks and troughs. Both vary.

persistent.gap: You do not understand Maxwell's equations linking E and B.
persistent.action: Core principle: changing E creates B, changing B creates E. This mutual creation enables propagation.

field_self_propagation.name: Field Self-Propagation
field_self_propagation.correct: EM waves propagate because a changing E field creates a changing B field, which creates a changing E field, and so on indefinitely.

requires a medium.error: EM waves do not need a medium; they propagate through vacuum.
requires a medium.fix: The fields regenerate each other. No particles are needed to carry the wave.
requires a medium.action: Light from stars travels through empty space. No medium required.

needs continuous source.error: Once created, EM waves propagate independently of the source.
needs continuous source.fix: The initial acceleration starts the wave; then fields sustain themselves.
needs continuous source.action: A brief flash creates a wave packet that travels forever without the source.

stops without matter.error: EM waves travel best in vacuum where there is no matter.
stops without matter.fix: Vacuum is ideal for EM propagation; matter can absorb or slow waves.
stops without matter.action: Space is vacuum. Light travels billions of years through empty space.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how EM waves sustain themselves.
persistent.action: Think chain reaction: E changes → makes B → B changes → makes E → repeat forever.

em_wave_speed.name: Speed of EM Waves
em_wave_speed.correct: All electromagnetic waves travel at the speed of light, c = 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s, in a vacuum regardless of frequency.

depends on frequency.error: In vacuum, all EM waves travel at c regardless of frequency.
depends on frequency.fix: Frequency affects wavelength but not speed in vacuum: c = fλ.
depends on frequency.action: Red and blue light have different λ but same speed c in vacuum.

depends on wavelength.error: Wavelength does not affect speed in vacuum.
depends on wavelength.fix: All EM waves, from radio to gamma, travel at c in vacuum.
depends on wavelength.action: Radio waves and X-rays both travel at 3 × 10⁸ m/s in vacuum.

faster than light.error: Nothing, including EM waves, travels faster than c in vacuum.
faster than light.fix: c is the maximum speed for any signal or energy transfer.
faster than light.action: c is the universal speed limit. EM waves travel exactly at this limit.

persistent.gap: You do not understand c as a universal constant for EM waves.
persistent.action: Memorise: all EM waves travel at c = 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s in vacuum. Frequency and wavelength adjust to maintain c = fλ.

wave_equation.name: Wave Equation
wave_equation.correct: For electromagnetic waves: speed equals frequency times wavelength. Since c is constant in vacuum, f and λ are inversely proportional.

c = f/λ.error: The formula is multiplication, not division.
c = f/λ.fix: c = fλ means c = f × λ.
c = f/λ.action: Check units: Hz × m = m/s. That gives speed. f/λ gives wrong units.

c = λ/f.fix: c = fλ, not λ/f. Speed = frequency times wavelength.
c = λ/f.action: Rearrange: λ = c/f, f = c/λ. Start from c = fλ.

c = f + λ.fix: You cannot add frequency (Hz) to wavelength (m). It is multiplication.
c = f + λ.action: Check dimensions: Hz + m is meaningless. Hz × m = m/s makes sense.

persistent.gap: You do not know the wave equation.
persistent.action: Memorise: c = fλ. Practice: if f doubles, λ halves to keep c constant.

em_spectrum_order.name: EM Spectrum Order
em_spectrum_order.formula: Radio → Micro → IR → Visible → UV → X-ray → Gamma
em_spectrum_order.correct: The EM spectrum ranges from low-frequency radio waves to high-frequency gamma rays, all travelling at c in vacuum.

visible light has highest frequency.error: UV, X-rays, and gamma rays all have higher frequencies than visible light.
visible light has highest frequency.fix: Visible is mid-spectrum. Higher frequency: UV, X-ray, gamma.
visible light has highest frequency.action: Order by frequency: radio (low) to gamma (high). Visible is in the middle.

radio waves are fastest.error: All EM waves travel at the same speed c in vacuum.
radio waves are fastest.fix: Radio waves have low frequency but same speed as gamma rays.
radio waves are fastest.action: Speed is constant at c. Only frequency and wavelength differ.

gamma rays are slowest.error: All EM waves travel at c regardless of type.
gamma rays are slowest.fix: Gamma rays have high frequency but travel at c like all EM waves.
gamma rays are slowest.action: Do not confuse frequency with speed. All EM waves have the same speed.

persistent.action: Two facts: (1) All EM waves travel at c. (2) Higher frequency = shorter wavelength. Speed is constant.

oscillating_charge.name: Oscillating Charge
oscillating_charge.correct: An oscillating charge produces EM radiation at the same frequency as its oscillation.

double the oscillation frequency.error: The EM wave frequency equals the charge oscillation frequency.
double the oscillation frequency.fix: One oscillation = one wave cycle. Frequencies match exactly.
double the oscillation frequency.action: If charge oscillates at 1000 Hz, it emits 1000 Hz EM radiation.

half the oscillation frequency.fix: EM frequency matches source frequency: f_wave = f_oscillation.
half the oscillation frequency.action: Each back-and-forth of the charge creates one wave cycle.

unrelated to oscillation frequency.fix: The charge's oscillation rate determines the wave's frequency.
unrelated to oscillation frequency.action: Faster oscillation = higher frequency radiation. Direct relationship.

persistent.gap: You do not see the connection between source motion and wave frequency.
persistent.action: Key principle: the source dictates the frequency. Oscillate faster = emit higher frequency waves.

no_medium_required.name: No Medium Required
no_medium_required.correct: Unlike mechanical waves, electromagnetic waves do not require a medium. They can travel through the vacuum of space.

needs air.error: EM waves travel through vacuum where there is no air.
needs air.fix: Light from the Sun travels through space to Earth. No air in space.
needs air.action: Space is vacuum. Sunlight still reaches us. No medium needed.

needs aether.error: The aether does not exist. This was disproven in 1887.
needs aether.fix: Michelson-Morley showed there is no aether. EM waves need no medium.
needs aether.action: Historical note: scientists once believed in aether. Experiments proved it wrong.

needs matter to carry energy.error: EM waves carry energy as field oscillations, not through matter.
needs matter to carry energy.fix: Energy is stored in the E and B fields themselves, not in particles.
needs matter to carry energy.action: Fields carry energy. No matter particles required for EM propagation.

persistent.gap: You are applying mechanical wave concepts to EM waves.
persistent.action: Mechanical waves need a medium (sound needs air). EM waves do not. Different physics.

maxwell_contribution.name: Maxwell's Contribution
maxwell_contribution.formula: Maxwell unified electricity, magnetism, and light
maxwell_contribution.correct: James Clerk Maxwell showed mathematically that changing electric and magnetic fields could propagate as waves at the speed of light, unifying electromagnetism and optics.

discovered the electron.error: Thomson discovered the electron. Maxwell unified EM theory.
discovered the electron.fix: Maxwell's equations showed light is an electromagnetic wave.
discovered the electron.action: Maxwell: EM theory. Thomson: electron. Know who did what.

discovered radioactivity.error: Becquerel discovered radioactivity. Maxwell worked on EM waves.
discovered radioactivity.fix: Maxwell showed E and B fields can propagate together as light.
discovered radioactivity.action: Maxwell: EM waves. Becquerel: radioactivity. Different discoveries.

invented the light bulb.error: Edison invented the practical light bulb. Maxwell explained what light is.
invented the light bulb.fix: Maxwell developed the theory; Edison developed a technology.
invented the light bulb.action: Theory vs application: Maxwell explained EM waves, Edison made bulbs.

persistent.gap: You do not know key figures in physics history.
persistent.action: Maxwell's equations unified electricity, magnetism, and light. This was 1865, before Einstein.
